evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary pushback control lapse: active tug instructor failed to stop at TRP. NEC: The required TRP stop/release point was reached but not complied with; Pushback movement continued beyond TRP until blast-fence contact

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary coordination failure: challenge/alert breakdown among ground crew. NEC: Crew held divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent; No timely effective challenge or stop warning occurred despite cues

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary environmental/marking deficiency at TRP. NEC: TRP marking visibility/prominence/placement was inadequate; The marking deficiency plausibly caused or materially enabled the TRP miss

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary mechanical or control-system failure. NEC: A tug or aircraft control/braking malfunction affected stopping; Corroboration exists via tests, diagnostics, or repeat failures

slot_statements.availability: The primary coordination failure involving challenge and alert breakdown among the ground crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the preliminary historical timeline (hist_t0_prelim).
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identified coordination failure is resistant to defeaters as alternative explanations or mitigating factors do not adequately account for the lack of effective challenge or stop warnings, nor the divergent assumptions among crew, confirming the root cause's validity in the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 event.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The root cause of communication breakdown fits key features including divergent assumptions held by crew members about stop-state or intent, and the absence of timely, effective challenge or stop warnings despite available cues, consistent with the observed behaviors and interactions in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident.

slot_statements.availability: The primary pushback control lapse involving the active tug instructor failing to stop at the TRP is documented and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the hist_t0_prelim phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The root event is resistant to common defeaters as it is supported by clear evidence of the tug instructor's failure to stop at the TRP, the NEC indicating non-compliance with the required stop point, and the physical consequence of blast-fence contact, leaving little room for alternative explanations.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: This root event fits key features of procedural deviations in pushback operations, specifically the failure to comply with the required TRP stop/release point, resulting in continued pushback movement beyond the TRP until blast-fence contact.

node.statement: The primary coordination failure involving challenge and alert breakdown among the ground crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the preliminary historical timeline (hist_t0_prelim).

assumptions: The absence of explicit mention of effective challenge or alert implies it did not occur
The continued movement beyond TRP despite cues indicates failure in coordination and alerting
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely challenge or alerting by ground crew preventing the pushback exceedance
If hardware or procedural deviations were the primary cause rather than communication breakdown

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H2 and H3 show the tug instructor and trainee had interaction and role changes but no effective challenge or alert prevented the pushback continuing beyond the TRP as per H4, supporting the presence of coordination failure as claimed.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in the extent of communication effectiveness and whether all cues were recognized or challenged

node.statement: The root cause of communication breakdown fits key features including divergent assumptions held by crew members about stop-state or intent, and the absence of timely, effective challenge or stop warnings despite available cues, consistent with the observed behaviors and interactions in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident.

assumptions: Crew interactions described reflect their assumptions about stop-state and intent
No other overriding mechanical or environmental causes dominate the incident
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely challenge or shared understanding of stop-state before TRP exceedance
If mechanical or environmental factors were primary causes rather than coordination failure

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H2 and H3 show divergent assumptions and lack of effective challenge between crew members during pushback; H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP despite cues, supporting the claim of communication breakdown fitting key features.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential missing detailed communication transcripts or cockpit voice recordings to fully confirm timing and content of challenges

node.statement: The primary pushback control lapse involving the active tug instructor failing to stop at the TRP is documented and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the hist_t0_prelim phase.

assumptions: The instructor had full control and awareness of the pushback operation at the time of passing the TRP
No mechanical or communication issues interfered with the instructor's ability to stop at the TRP
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was not visible or marked adequately to explain the miss without instructor lapse
If mechanical control failures were documented that forced the pushback beyond TRP
If communication breakdown prevented the instructor from knowing the TRP stop requirement

quotes.exact_quote: After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H3 shows the instructor actively controlling pushback and attentive, while H4 documents the aircraft passing the TRP and colliding with the blast fence, supporting the claim of a procedural lapse by the active tug instructor.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: This root event fits key features of procedural deviations in pushback operations, specifically the failure to comply with the required TRP stop/release point, resulting in continued pushback movement beyond the TRP until blast-fence contact.

assumptions: The continued movement beyond TRP with engine at idle implies lack of braking or stopping action by the tug instructor rather than mechanical failure.
No evidence of mechanical faults was presented in the provided history.
defeaters: If evidence showed verified braking or control faults causing uncontrolled movement beyond TRP, or if the tug instructor was not actively controlling pushback at TRP exceedance, this would favor R4.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly states the aircraft passed the TRP and continued moving until blast-fence contact, supporting the procedural deviation hypothesis (R1) over mechanical failure (R4).
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence on mechanical system status or tug instructor's control inputs at TRP exceedance; possible ambiguity if mechanical failure was subtle or unreported.

node.statement: The identified coordination failure is resistant to defeaters as alternative explanations or mitigating factors do not adequately account for the lack of effective challenge or stop warnings, nor the divergent assumptions among crew, confirming the root cause's validity in the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 event.

assumptions: The lack of mention of hardware faults or mechanical issues implies no mechanical failure evidence was found.
Crew communication breakdown is inferred from the continued movement beyond TRP despite cues.
defeaters: If evidence showed hardware faults or repeat malfunctions causing the event, or if fault codes indicated mechanical failure, this would challenge the coordination failure root cause.
If crew communication or assumptions were shown to be aligned and effective challenge was present, this would weaken the coordination failure explanation.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP despite cues, supporting coordination failure (R2) over mechanical failure (R4). This supports the claim that alternative explanations do not adequately account for the lack of effective challenge or stop warnings.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

slot_statements.availability: The primary mechanical or control-system failure was present and detectable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as evidenced by preliminary historical data and diagnostics.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The conclusion of a primary mechanical or control-system failure is resistant to defeaters, supported by multiple independent tests, diagnostics, and repeat failure occurrences that rule out alternative explanations in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The failure aligns with key features of tug or aircraft control/braking malfunctions that affected stopping, consistent with observed symptoms and corroborated by tests and repeat failures in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident.

slot_statements.availability: The primary environmental or marking deficiency at TRP was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t0_prelim timeframe.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: No credible evidence or alternative explanations effectively refute the claim that the inadequate TRP marking visibility, prominence, and placement caused or materially enabled the TRP miss in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t0_prelim context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The deficiency in TRP marking visibility, prominence, and placement aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t0_prelim data, supporting its relevance to the incident.

node.statement: The primary mechanical or control-system failure was present and detectable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as evidenced by preliminary historical data and diagnostics.

defeaters: If fault codes, diagnostics, or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical/control failure were found
If tests or diagnostics showed a tug or aircraft control/braking malfunction

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly shows the aircraft passed the TRP with engine at idle and collided with the blast barrier, indicating no corroborated mechanical or control-system failure; H1-H3 describe crew actions but no hardware faults.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: The primary environmental or marking deficiency at TRP was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t0_prelim timeframe.

assumptions: Presence of TRP marking implies it was observable and primary deficiency relates to marking availability
No contradictory evidence about marking adequacy is present in the provided history
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP marking was not visible or poorly placed during the timeframe
If crew or tug driver statements indicated confusion or inability to see the TRP marking
If mechanical control failure evidence explained the continued movement beyond TRP

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: H4 directly shows the aircraft passed the TRP marking despite engine idle, indicating the marking was present but the miss occurred; no evidence indicates marking was inadequate or not observable.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of explicit evidence about marking visibility or prominence; only presence is confirmed

node.statement: The deficiency in TRP marking visibility, prominence, and placement aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t0_prelim data, supporting its relevance to the incident.

assumptions: The continued movement beyond the TRP despite engine idle implies marking visibility or placement deficiency.
No direct evidence contradicts the marking deficiency hypothesis in the provided data.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, prominent TRP markings and crew awareness of the TRP, or control system malfunction evidence, the conclusion might shift.
If communication breakdown or procedural deviation evidence was stronger, it could favor alternative hypotheses.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly shows the aircraft passed the TRP marking and collided with the blast barrier, supporting that TRP marking visibility/prominence/placement was inadequate and relevant to the incident, favoring R3 over alternatives.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew attention and communication details; lack of explicit evidence on marking visibility quality

node.statement: No credible evidence or alternative explanations effectively refute the claim that the inadequate TRP marking visibility, prominence, and placement caused or materially enabled the TRP miss in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t0_prelim context.

assumptions: The TRP marking visibility/prominence/placement was inadequate enough to explain the miss absent attention lapse.
No credible evidence of procedural deviation or other causes outweighs the marking deficiency explanation.
defeaters: If evidence showed crew recognized TRP and expected stopping but continued motion due to procedural deviation, this would favor R1 and refute the claim.
If clear alternative explanations such as mechanical failure or communication breakdown were supported by evidence, they could refute the claim.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly shows the aircraft passed the TRP despite engine idle, indicating inadequate TRP marking visibility/prominence/placement plausibly caused or materially enabled the miss, supporting the claim and favoring R3 over R1.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of explicit evidence on crew recognition or attention to TRP and absence of detailed marking visibility assessment

children_spec.statement: The TRP marking was physically present and not obscured at the time of the incident

children_spec.statement: The TRP marking was placed in a location consistent with regulatory and operational standards

children_spec.statement: The TRP marking was maintained in a condition that ensured its visibility and prominence (e.g., not faded or damaged)
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect maintenance records and physical evidence to assess the condition of the TRP marking at the time of the incident

node.statement: The TRP marking was placed in a location consistent with regulatory and operational standards

Testimony or data indicating the crew recognized and intended to stop at the TRP but failed due to other factors

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

node.statement: The root event is resistant to common defeaters as it is supported by clear evidence of the tug instructor's failure to stop at the TRP, the NEC indicating non-compliance with the required stop point, and the physical consequence of blast-fence contact, leaving little room for alternative explanations.

assumptions: The TRP was clearly marked and visible to the tug instructor
No mechanical or braking faults occurred during pushback
Communication of TRP stop-state was clear and understood
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP stop-state was not communicated or understood (supporting R2)
If evidence showed verified mechanical or braking faults (supporting R4)
If evidence showed inadequate TRP visibility or marking (supporting R3)

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly shows the tug instructor failed to stop at the TRP and the pushback continued until blast-fence contact, supporting resistance to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence on communication clarity, mechanical faults, or TRP visibility; assumptions made that these were not factors.

node.statement: No environmental or situational factors prevented ground crew from receiving or sending challenge/alert messages

No direct evidence of environmental or situational factors explicitly preventing message exchange

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

node.statement: The failure aligns with key features of tug or aircraft control/braking malfunctions that affected stopping, consistent with observed symptoms and corroborated by tests and repeat failures in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident.

No contradictory evidence from procedural or communication failures outweighs the mechanical failure hypothesis.
defeaters: If evidence showed the tug or aircraft controls were functioning normally or if procedural deviations or communication breakdowns better explained the failure to stop, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

No contradictory evidence from communication or procedural deviations is present

The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
